fields.value: Levy foraging patterns of rural humans

dsDescriptionValue.value: This is a series of Google Earth satellite images to illustrate GPS trajectories measured in the field by rural humans in one location in Mexico (La Montaña, Guerrero) and two locations in Brazil (Roraima and Ceara) while performing foraging activities in the wild.

publicationCitation.value: Reynolds A, Ceccon E, Baldauf C, Karina Medeiros T, Miramontes O (2018) Lévy foraging patterns of rural humans. PLoS ONE 13(6): e0199099. https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pone.0199099

files.description: FIG4_B (Inset figure in the manuscript) shows an inward-outward trajectory overlaid on the almost straight line geometry of the dirt road. The meandering of the walker is evident. Trajectory is a segment of the full trajectory on Figure 4. La Montaña de Guerrero, Mexico. Location:  17°13'47.48"N  98°59'21.21"W. Image courtesy of Google Inc , INEGI and DigitalGlobe Inc.
files.label: FIG4_B.jpg

dataFile.description: FIG4_B (Inset figure in the manuscript) shows an inward-outward trajectory overlaid on the almost straight line geometry of the dirt road. The meandering of the walker is evident. Trajectory is a segment of the full trajectory on Figure 4. La Montaña de Guerrero, Mexico. Location:  17°13'47.48"N  98°59'21.21"W. Image courtesy of Google Inc , INEGI and DigitalGlobe Inc.

files.description:
Figure 4. Trail following by the Me’Phaa out of Agua Tordillo small village. This is a typical
example of a GPS recorded trajectory followed by an individual while executing a
firewood searching exploration in the Guerrero Mountains in Mexico. The full trajectory is depicted overlaid in the top picture showing the local topography and roads. Location:  17°13'36.49"N  98°59'14.89"W. Image courtesy of Google Inc , INEGI and DigitalGlobe Inc.
files.label: FIG4_GE.png

files.description: Figure 5. Trail following by the Brazilian Cariri gatherers. Typical example of a GPS recorded trajectory followed by an individual while executing a fruit gathering exploration in the Chapada do Araripe, Brazil exhibiting the local landscape as well.  Location:   7°22'21.35"S  39°24'31.08"W. Image courtesy of Google Inc. and DigitalGlobe Inc.
files.label: FIG5_GE.png

dataFile.description: Figure 5. Trail following by the Brazilian Cariri gatherers. Typical example of a GPS recorded trajectory followed by an individual while executing a fruit gathering exploration in the Chapada do Araripe, Brazil exhibiting the local landscape as well.  Location:   7°22'21.35"S  39°24'31.08"W. Image courtesy of Google Inc. and DigitalGlobe Inc.

files.description:
Figure 6 Typical example of a GPS recorded trajectory followed by an individual while
executing a nut gathering excursion in the Amazonian rainforest in Rondônia, Brazil exhibiting the local terrain features as well. In some cases forest features (i.e. changes in canopy density) other than footpaths are used when walking, these may include the borders of forest gaps where vegetation is secondary or primary and is somewhat more easy to walk. Location 10°53'40.68" S, 65°03'44.68"W. Image courtesy of Google Inc. and DigitalGlobe Inc.
files.label: FIG6_GE.png

dataFile.description:
Figure 6 Typical example of a GPS recorded trajectory followed by an individual while
executing a nut gathering excursion in the Amazonian rainforest in Rondônia, Brazil exhibiting the local terrain features as well. In some cases forest features (i.e. changes in canopy density) other than footpaths are used when walking, these may include the borders of forest gaps where vegetation is secondary or primary and is somewhat more easy to walk. Location 10°53'40.68" S, 65°03'44.68"W. Image courtesy of Google Inc. and DigitalGlobe Inc.

files.description:
Figure 7. Feature following by the Hadza. A GPS recorded trajectory followed by an
individual while executing a foraging trip, south of lake Eyasi in the Arusha region of Tanzania, and overlaid on the local landscape (trajectory in blue from graph 2a in Raichlen et al, 2014). In the image, the individual
follows terrain features such a dry river basin (D). Also a network of footpaths is evident (F). It remains to be seen whether or not feature and/or trailing following is evident in any other of 341 Hadza recorded trajectories. Location:   3°43'47.63"S  35°10'59.81"E. Image courtesy of Google Inc. and DigitalGlobe Inc.
files.label: FIG_7NEW.jpg

dataFile.description:
Figure 7. Feature following by the Hadza. A GPS recorded trajectory followed by an
individual while executing a foraging trip, south of lake Eyasi in the Arusha region of Tanzania, and overlaid on the local landscape (trajectory in blue from graph 2a in Raichlen et al, 2014). In the image, the individual
follows terrain features such a dry river basin (D). Also a network of footpaths is evident (F). It remains to be seen whether or not feature and/or trailing following is evident in any other of 341 Hadza recorded trajectories. Location:   3°43'47.63"S  35°10'59.81"E. Image courtesy of Google Inc. and DigitalGlobe Inc.

files.description:
Supplementary Material Figure 2. Feature following by the Me’Phaa. This is a typical example of a GPS recorded trajectory followed by an individual while executing a firewood searching exploration in the Guerrero Mountains in Mexico. The full trajectory is depicted overlaid in the top picture showing the local landscape. In the bottom picture the physical features in the terrain used for walking and reaching a
foraging site is evident. E is an eroded slope, F marks a portion of a used footpath network. The Google Earth satellite image is courtesy of 2016 Google Inc., 2016 INEGI and 2016 DigitalGlobe.
files.label: SM002.png

Araripe, Brazil exhibiting the local landscape as well. In the bottom picture the physical features are evident. D is a dirt road while F marks portions of a footpath network. The Google Earth satellite image is courtesy of 2016 Google Inc., 2016 Astrium and 2016 DigitalGlobe.

files.description:
Supplementary Material Figure 7. Feature following by Brazilian gatherers in the Amazonian rainforest in Rondônia. Typical example of a GPS recorded trajectory of an individual while executing a nut gathering
exploration. Due to the dense nature of the tree canopy, small trails and footpaths on the ground are sometimes difficult to spot. Forest features (i.e. changes in canopy density) other than footpaths are often used, these may include the borders of forest gaps (B) where vegetation is secondary or absent
and is somewhat more easy to walk. The Google Earth satellite image is courtesy of 2016 Google Inc., 2016 CNES/SPOT, 2016 DigitalGlobe and US Dept of State Geographer.
files.label: SM007.png
